children.text: Lorde talks about how she injured her shoulder by falling up the stairs and jokes with the interviewer about falling up stairs being more common than people think. She's back in New Zealand for her sister's graduation and other family celebrations.

Watching her sister graduate made Lorde reflect on her own experience as a high school dropout. She expresses admiration for the graduates and contemplates returning to traditional education someday. She values abstract learning through her music career, but craves structured academic learning and the traditional education system.

Lorde discusses the non-traditional education she gains through music production and building live shows. She explains her role as a producer on her latest album and how she’s had to learn about lighting, set design, and video direction for performances like Coachella.

The interviewer asks about how IMelodrama differs from Pure Heroine. Lorde says the new album is a natural evolution, but there are still familiar melodic elements. She sees it as a continuation of her story and a snapshot of her life a few years later.

Reflecting on how she's changed since her debut, Lorde says the time between 16 and 20 brings natural growth. Being in the music industry forced her to mature quickly by having to lead meetings, run a business, and handle collaborations. Emotional changes like moving out and breakups also contributed to her growth.

Lorde shares how personal experiences like breakups and collaborations, specifically with Jack Antonoff, helped her grow as a person and artist. These moments all inform her music and emotional development, shaping the themes of her latest work.

She clarifies Melodrama isn’t a breakup record, but rather explores what happens after a breakup such as the “magic of being alone.” Living on her own for the first time allowed her to process her emotions and build a personal and introspective record.

Lorde says she didn’t feel immediate loneliness post-breakup; it crept in later. The emotional impact wasn’t linear and at first she partied a lot. However, the deeper processing came months after. She talks about how healing happens in stages.

Lorde expresses pride in Melodrama being finished, despite the pressure to follow up the success of Pure Heroine. She says it’s rich with secrets and discovery and isn’t a “one-listen” album. She hopes fans will really dig into it and understand it for what it is regardless of any expectations.

The interviewer asks Lorde if she is a fan of herself and Lorde shuts that down because she feels she can't be too close to the process and “can’t fall for the highs and lows” she created. She adds she doesn’t control what she creates, but that she’s just translating what’s in her brain.

She expands on the creative process and states that if the music is cool or weird, it’s simply a reflection of her inner world. She jokes she might be freaked out if she were a fan of herself because it’d feel too “on the nose."

The interviewer plays a rapid-fire game called “In One Word.” Lorde answers that if she weren’t in music, she’d make perfume since she’s a passionate fragrance collector and believes she'd be good at creating scents. She says she’d live in the UK if not New Zealand, but struggles to come up with an alternate stage name. When asked about the hottest guy on Earth, she confidently says Brad Pitt and laughs that meeting him would be “too much to process.”

The game continues. Lorde’s favorite baby name is “Robin,” inspired by her friend’s new baby, Oscar Robin. When asked if she wants kids, she answers “deeply” and says she comes from a big family, but doesn’t see parenthood in her near future because she still has work to do.

Asked what she’d study if she were at university, Lorde initially leans toward English or classics due to her background, but playfully suggests biology to shake things up even though she admits she’d likely be terrible at it.

The interviewer asks if anything in her childhood helped shape her. Lorde says she was read to and sung to a lot, which is common among musicians. She was a shy kid with a rich inner world, and she feels that this is something that feeds into her songwriting.

She talks about how her early sensory experiences shaped her curiosity and imagination.The interviewer gifts her a secondhand Laura Nyro CD, on recommendation from Alice Cooper, who is a fan of Lorde and thinks she should listen to Nyro’s second album. Lorde is surprised and grateful even though she does not have a CD player.
